message.content: We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s symptoms and X-ray findings are indicative of osteoarthritis. Nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs (NSAIDs) such as ibuprofen are indicated for symptomatic relief in osteoarthritis patients. Intra-articular glucocorticoid injections may be considered if the patient doesn’t respond to oral NSAIDs. Methotrexate and celecoxib are not recommended in osteoarthritis patients.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s symptoms and x-ray findings suggest osteoarthritis. Ibuprofen is an appropriate pharmacotherapy for pain relief in this condition. Intra-articular glucocorticoid injections are also an option for symptom relief, but given the bilateral knee involvement, oral medication is more appropriate. Celecoxib is a selective COX-2 inhibitor and may have a role in managing osteoarthritis, but is not the first choice. Methotrexate is used in the treatment of rheumatoid arthritis but is not indicated in osteoarthritis.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s symptoms and X-ray findings are consistent with osteoarthritis. Among the options, ibuprofen is the most appropriate pharmacotherapy for treating the pain and inflammation associated with osteoarthritis. Intra-articular glucocorticoid injections can be used for symptomatic relief, but are not the first line of treatment. Celecoxib is a COX-2 inhibitor that is used in cases where ibuprofen is not effective or have gastrointestinal side effects. Methotrexate is used for rheumatoid arthritis and not for osteoarthritis.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. Given the patient's symptoms, joint x-ray results, and lack of swelling or reddening, the most appropriate pharmacotherapy is administration of ibuprofen for management of osteoarthritis pain. Intra-articular glucocorticoid injections may be beneficial for some patients with osteoarthritis, but the patient's symptoms and x-ray findings suggest that systemic treatment is appropriate at this time. Celecoxib is an NSAID and can be considered, but ibuprofen is a more appropriate choice for initial treatment. Methotrexate is not used to treat osteoarthritis and is more commonly used for autoimmune diseases such as rheumatoid arthritis.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s symptoms and X-ray findings suggest osteoarthritis. Among the options, ibuprofen is the most appropriate pharmacotherapy for osteoarthritis pain. Intra-articular glucocorticoid injections can also provide pain relief but are generally reserved for more severe cases. Celecoxib is a COX-2 inhibitor and can be used to treat osteoarthritis but the patient has a history of type 2 diabetes mellitus, which is a contraindication. Methotrexate is used to treat rheumatoid arthritis, not osteoarthritis.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms and examination findings suggest osteoarthritis, which is often treated with nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs (NSAIDs) like ibuprofen. Intra-articular glucocorticoid injections may provide temporary relief but are not a long-term solution for the patient. Celecoxib is a type of NSAID but it is not recommended for patients with diabetes mellitus. Methotrexate is used to treat rheumatoid arthritis, which is not the diagnosis in this case.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms and imaging findings suggest osteoarthritis, and among the options, only ibuprofen is recommended for the treatment of osteoarthritis pain. Intra-articular glucocorticoid injections may be used in severe cases, but it’s not the initial treatment. Methotrexate is mainly used for rheumatoid arthritis, and celecoxib is contraindicated in patients with a history of coronary artery bypass graft surgery.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s symptoms and x-ray findings are consistent with osteoarthritis. While all options can help manage the symptoms of osteoarthritis, ibuprofen is the most appropriate for initial treatment as it is a nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drug (NSAID) that can provide pain relief and reduce inflammation. Intra-articular glucocorticoid injections may be considered for those who cannot tolerate NSAIDs or have contraindications. Celecoxib is also an NSAID but may have more potential for adverse effects. Methotrexate is not typically used for osteoarthritis.

The patient’s symptoms and X-ray findings suggest osteoarthritis, and among the options, ibuprofen is the most appropriate pharmacotherapy for osteoarthritis pain relief. Intra-articular glucocorticoid injections can provide temporary relief but it is not a long term solution. Celecoxib and methotrexate are not typically used to treat osteoarthritis.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient's symptoms and X-ray findings suggest that she has osteoarthritis. Among the options, the most appropriate pharmacotherapy would be administration of ibuprofen, a nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drug (NSAID), for pain relief. Intra-articular glucocorticoid injections or methotrexate may be used in rheumatoid arthritis, but are not effective in osteoarthritis. Celecoxib, a selective COX-2 inhibitor, may be used in osteoarthritis but is contraindicated in patients with a history of cardiovascular disease, such as the patient's type 2 diabetes mellitus.
